title: Kidnappers may have started new tactic to try and get victims in Flint | Metro News
text:
Georgia Diebelius for Metro.co.uk Wednesday 22 Feb 2017 1:12 pm Ashley drove to a safe space before removing the shirt (Facebook/Ashley Hardacre) 
A teenager was left terrified after discovering a shirt on her car windscreen – a new tactic allegedly used by kidnappers. 
Ashley Hardacre had just finished her shift at a shopping centre in Flint, Michigan, when she spotted the flannel top wrapped around her windscreen wiper. Shocking video footage shows Harrison Ford missed crashing his plane in California by a whisker 
After attempting to remove the clothing by turning the car on, she noticed two other cars hovering nearby – one with the engine running. 
The 19-year-old said she immediately felt uneasy so decided not to get out of the car, and instead drive away. 
Speaking to Metro.co.uk , she said: ‘My initial thought was that someone had just thrown it on my car for some reason. Ashley spoke out following the ordeal (Picture: Facebook/Ashley Hardacre) She was left terrified (Picture: Facebook/Ashley Hardacre) 
‘But when I tried to use my wipers to get it off I noticed it was wrapped around and I knew it was intentional, so I got scared.’ 
After driving half a mile, Ashley pulled over near a restaurant and leaned out of the window to free the shirt from the screen. Police sent seven dead victims of Croydon tram crash invites to survivors’ group 
She added: ‘I was very scared. My family and friends are all scared and worried, but they are very proud that I am spreading awareness. 
‘I’m nervous while walking to my car now, but I do have security with me now to protect me.’ 
Following the incident, Ashley took to Facebook to reveal the incident. 
She said: ‘There were two cars near me and one was running so I immediately felt uneasy and knew I couldn’t get out to get it off. 
‘I had seen posts lately about people finding things under their windshield wipers in the Flint area as an attempt to get girls out of their cars and distracted. Peggy, 96, has been volunteering at a homeless shelter for 80 years 
‘I don’t know why the shirt was on my car but it had to have been intentional the way it was put on there. 
‘I really can’t think of another reason as to why someone would put it on my car.’ 
Security at the establishment where Ashley works now guide her to her car each evening. 
Local police have also been informed of the incident. More
